intro: Peucedanum parisiense, commonly known as the Paris bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to central and eastern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white to pale blue flowers. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges or meadows. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
